title: AirLife FlowMate Oxygen Flowmeter - Gauge / Meter Malfunction
description: Troubleshoot inaccurate, erratic, or unresponsive AirLife FlowMate oxygen flowmeter readings by checking external factors before repair.

steps.title: Verify the Gas Source
steps.instructions: Ensure the oxygen cylinder or pipeline supply is turned on. Confirm that the supply pressure is within the recommended range for the FlowMate (typically 50–60 psi).

steps.title: Inspect the Connection
steps.instructions: Check that the flowmeter is fully seated on the regulator or manifold. Examine inlet threads for damage or debris.

steps.title: Check for Obstructions
steps.instructions: Remove tubing from the outlet and visually inspect the flow path. Look for kinks, moisture, or particulate matter in the tubing.

steps.title: Test with Another Flowmeter
steps.instructions: If available, attach a known-good flowmeter to the same source. Compare readings at identical settings.

steps.title: Environmental Factors
steps.instructions: Ensure the device is not exposed to extreme vibration, tilt, or temperature fluctuations. The FlowMate should remain upright on a stable surface.

steps.title: Check for Visible Damage
steps.instructions: Inspect the gauge face, needle, and housing for cracks, dents, or internal moisture.

CCR.Complaint: Flowmeter needle jumps and reads inaccurately at all settings.
CCR.Cause: Upon inspection, supply pressure and connections were normal; tubing clear; device tested on stable surface; meter still inaccurate.
CCR.Resolution: Flowmeter removed from service, labeled Out of Service, sent for repair.

helpfulDetails: Any visible damage or moisture inside gauge

title: AirLife FlowMate Oxygen Flowmeter - Leaks / Hissing Sounds
description: Guide to troubleshoot hissing sounds and leaks in the AirLife FlowMate oxygen flowmeter, focusing on external checks before internal repair.

steps.title: Ensure Device is Off / Safe to Inspect
steps.instructions: Confirm the oxygen source is off and the patient has been moved to another device if in use. Patient safety is priority; never troubleshoot a flowmeter under active patient use.

steps.title: Inspect Connections and Fittings
steps.instructions: Check inlet and outlet connections for tightness. Inspect for any misaligned or cross-threaded fittings. Loose connections are a common cause of hissing leaks.

steps.title: Examine Tubing and Attachments
steps.instructions: Look for cracks, splits, or worn areas in oxygen tubing. Replace any tubing showing wear. Ensure all tubing is fully seated on barbed connectors.

steps.title: Check Flowmeter Orientation and Installation
steps.instructions: Confirm the flowmeter is upright and properly mounted according to manufacturer guidance. Flowmeters that are tilted or improperly seated can leak or produce noise.

steps.title: Test the Needle Valve and Flow Adjustment Knob
steps.instructions: Slowly adjust the flow from zero to the prescribed setting. Listen for persistent hissing at full or mid-range flow. A hissing that persists regardless of flow setting may indicate an internal leak.

steps.title: Check for External Obstructions
steps.instructions: Remove any humidifiers, adapters, or connectors temporarily. Test the flowmeter alone to determine if an accessory is causing the noise or leak.

CCR.Complaint: Flowmeter makes hissing sound and may be leaking oxygen.
CCR.Cause: Observed loose tubing, misaligned connections, and persistent hissing despite proper setup.
CCR.Resolution: Tightened connections and replaced worn tubing. If leak persisted, flowmeter removed from service and labeled Out of Service for repair.

helpfulDetails: Location of leak or hissing sound
Final device status: functional after tubing/fittings corrected or sent for repair

title: AirLife FlowMate Oxygen Flowmeter - No or Low Flow
description: Troubleshooting guide for situations where the AirLife FlowMate oxygen flowmeter produces no or reduced oxygen flow, focusing on external causes first.

steps.title: Verify Oxygen Source
steps.instructions: Confirm the wall outlet or oxygen cylinder is turned on and has adequate pressure. Reason: A closed or depleted source is the most common cause of no or low flow.

steps.title: Check Supply Pressure
steps.instructions: Use a wall flow gauge or cylinder pressure gauge to ensure pressure meets manufacturer specifications. Reason: Low source pressure can reduce flow or prevent the flowmeter from operating.

steps.title: Inspect Connections
steps.instructions: Verify tubing is correctly attached at both the flowmeter inlet and patient interface. Look for kinks, twists, or tight bends in tubing. Reason: Obstructions in the tubing restrict flow.

steps.title: Check Flowmeter Valve / Knob
steps.instructions: Turn the flow adjustment knob fully off and then back on slowly. Observe if the flow indicator moves. Reason: Knob position or a stuck valve may prevent flow.

steps.title: Inspect Flowmeter Chamber and Indicator
steps.instructions: Ensure the float (ball or bobbin) moves freely and is not jammed. Clean if necessary following safe external procedures. Reason: A stuck float gives false readings or prevents flow.

steps.title: Test with Alternate Tubing or Outlet
steps.instructions: Swap the oxygen tubing and/or connect to a different oxygen source. Reason: Confirms whether the issue is with the flowmeter or external supply.

steps.title: Observe for Leaks
steps.instructions: Listen for hissing around connections. Tighten fittings if loose; do not overtighten plastic fittings. Reason: Leaks reduce or eliminate oxygen delivery.

CCR.Complaint: User reports “Oxygen flow is low or not present” on the FlowMate flowmeter.
CCR.Cause: Observed low source pressure from wall outlet; tubing kinked at elbow connector; flowmeter float stuck intermittently.
CCR.Resolution: Straightened tubing, verified source pressure, cleaned float chamber, confirmed proper flow. Device returned to service. If unresolved, removed and sent for repair with “Out of Service” label.
